newsitem.title: UK: NWE high sulphur fuel stable, bunker demand poor.
newsitem.headline: NWE high sulphur fuel stable, bunker demand poor.

text.p: NWE high sulphur cracked fuel oil was stable on Friday amid poor bunker demand, traders said.
Prompt high sulphur barges traded at $98 fob ARA, while barges for the first decade of February traded $4 higher. Dealers said the lack of bunkering enquiry was depressing demand for prompt barrels.
High sulphur cargo numbers were notionally flat to barges, with February cif cargo swaps flat to barge swaps at around $99/$100 a tonne.
An ARA player was believed to be seeking cargo product, with offers pegged at around a dollar or two over swaps levels.

An Italian refiner was seeking high sulphur barrels for mid to late February. The requirement was for three percent sulphur, ENEL-quality barrels. He expected the requirement to be covered from Italy.
The refiner was also seeking 25,000 tonnes of low sulphur fuel for late next month, and said offers were easy to find.
Dealers said low sulphur fuel was still well supplied although trade on Thursday at around $106 fob NWE had taken some of the length out of the market.
